questions.question: For a patient presenting with gradual, painless diminution of vision, the differential diagnosiswould not include
What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?
questions.explanation: 563The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellens chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability todiscriminate between two points. Snellens chart is used for Visual acuity assesment.In snellens chart the alphabets decrease in size as we move from above-downwards and theselines, from above-downwards should be read at 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5 and 4 m respectively. Atthese distances, the respective letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Hence, the largestalphabet that should be read at 60 m subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.ED-365' of arc1' of arcHD-24NK RD-18U OP CD-12LDETRD-9ABNC PVD-6RVTNF DOSnellen's AnglesEach stroke → 1 min arcTotal Stroke, E-5 min arc36 mPerson viewing6 times inwardMARROEEach stroke 6 min arc6 x 5 30 min of arcOMARROW6 mPerson viewing

questions.question: A 60-year-old man comes to the OPD for an eye exam. He is having difficulty readingnewspapers but has no problem watching television. At what distance would you ask him toread a Jaeger's chart from?
questions.explanation: Jaeger's chart is held at a distance of 35 cm away from the patient.564It is used to measure near vision. The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest asN48. Snellen's near vision chart can also be used.The image below shows a Jaeger's chart.No. 7.1.50Mable treaty, the restitution of the standards and prisonerswhich had been taken in the defeat of Crassus.His gon-erals, in the early part of his reign, attempted the reductionof Ethiopia and Arabia Felix. They marched near a tho-1.75Msand miles to the south of the tropic; but the heat ofthe climate soon repelled the invaders, and protectedthe unwarlike natives of those sequestered regionsNo. 9.2.00MThe northern countries ofserved the expense andThe forestsfilled withand morasseseNo. 10L2.25MEurope scarcely de-labor of conquest.of Germany werehardy race of barbarianswho despised life when it was separatedfrom freedom; and though, on the firstattack,to thepower,No. 112.50Mthey seemed to yieldweight of theRomanthey soon, by a signalGRAHAN-FIELD

questions.question: A patient is being evaluated for a recent eye injury. The result of his Placido disc test is shownbelow. What is the correct interpretation?551
questions.explanation: The given Placido's disc test result indicates a normal corneal surface.This test is used to detect an abnormal corneal surface. Irregularities of the corneal surfacecause distortion of the circles.Distortion of the circle is seen in keratoconus, keratoglobus, corneal ulcer, and corneal abrasion.Placido's disc testNormalEqually spacedsymmetrical ringsAspherical corneaNon equidistant ringsCorneal astigmatismOval shaped ringsKeratoconusInferior steepening of ringsOMARROW565

questions.question: A patient presents with the following finding in his eye. Fluorescein staining is done and theeye is observed under cobalt blue light. What would be seen?
questions.explanation: The image shows a corneal ulcer. The ulcer takes the stain and appears brilliant green, and whenexamined under cobalt blue light, it appears opaque green.AB

questions.question: A 61-year-old man, known case of diabetes mellitus, presented with headache and eye pain.He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Visual field-testing indicates peripheral visionloss. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument during his examination of thispatient. What is he measuring by using the following instrument?
questions.explanation: The instrument shown is the Schiotz tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure(IOP).This patient's complaints of headache, eye pain, difficulty in adapting to darkness, andexamination findings of peripheral vision loss with increased intraocular pressure, is suggestive ofglaucoma.Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer. The principle behind its use is thatthe plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?553

options.A: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
options.B: It is used to treat after cataract
options.C: It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
options.D: It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.explanation: The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocularpressure (IOP).The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. It is based on Imbert-Fick law,which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten itssurface divided by the area of flattening (A).P = W/AThe different types are Goldmann tonometer, Perkin's tonometer, pneumatic tonometer, pulse airtonometer, tono-pen.566

questions.question: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for his myopia. He is now complaining ofheadaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on him.
questions.explanation: The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamiccontour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP)measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type oftonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of choice in post-Lasikpatients.Option A: Pachymetry is used to measure the corneal thickness.The below image is of pachymetry.42READRECALLPRINT0CE39RESET6+ENTEROption C: Auto Refractotemetry is a computerized refractometer that is used to find out the errorof refraction. This gives rapid information about the kind of refractive error in terms of sphere,cylinder with axis and inter pupillary distance.Option D: A-Scan ultrasonography is a useful diagnostic tool for intraocular evaluation especiallyin the setting of opaque media. The report of the A scan is displayed as a unidimensional displayof spikes along a baseline where the distance between the spikes gives the indirect measurementof the tissues. A-scan is used to measure• The axial length of the eyeball for Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation• Anterior chamber depth• Thickness of intraocular mass.A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.567Axa

questions.question: You can use any of the following to estimate the visual field of a patient except:
questions.explanation: Optical coherence tomography is not used to estimate the visual field. It is a non-invasive imagingtechnique to visualize cross-sections of the retina.Perimetry is used to estimate the visual field.•Types:Manual perimetry- Confrontation method, Lister's perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry),Goldmann's perimeter•Automated perimetry- Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field AnalyzerThe images given below shows Lister's perimeter568Confrontation methodOMARROWThe image below shows a multifixation campimeter study result.MULTIFIXATION CAMPIMETER1419, ChinaDiagnosis: HeatingLEFT EYE20Type in a name for the image you want to save:missed6seen 1stseen 2ndseen 3rdnot testedRIGHT EYE35F, TeacherAge25 November 2005PRINTBACKSAVE bmp

questions.question: Which among the following phases indicate complete filling of the retinal arterioles andcapillaries on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.explanation: Complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries is seen in the arterio-venous phase.In FFA, sodium fluorescein dye is injected into the antecubital vein. A fundus camera is then usedto take photographs:•1st picture- after 5 seconds, then every second for 20 seconds, every 3-5 seconds for the next 1minute• Last picture- after 10 minutes•Pre-arterial phase- choroidal circulation is filling569• Arterial phase- start filling of retinal arteriole till its completely filled• Arterio-venous phase- complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries followed by laminarfilling of veins•⚫ Venous filling- arterioles are emptying and veins are fillingIndications for fundus fluorescein angiography:•Diabetic retinopathy• Vascular occlusion•Eale's disease• Central serous retinopathy• Cystoid macular edema

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with diabetes presents with complaints of dark floating spots andflashes of light in her left eye. Optical coherence tomography of the left eye is given in theimage below. Identify the pathology.555
questions.explanation: The image shows vitreomacular traction with detached posterior vitreous membrane and fovealtraction.OCT images:1. Normal OCT570VitreousNerve fiber layerFoveaRetinal Pigment EpitheliumChoroid2. Vitreomacular traction- The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), asindicated by the arrow. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion may also be seen at the siteof traction.3. Vitreomacular adhesion- posterior vitreous detachment but no macular or foveal traction. Theretinal morphology is normal.5714. Macular hole - a partial or full-thickness retinal defect is seen.A full-thickness macular hole is seen in the image below.5. Central serous retinopathy- fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinaldetachment.5722726. Cystoid macular edema - loss of foveal depression with cystoid spaces in the retina.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female, who is a known case of type 2 diabetes, is undergoing serialelectroretinograms to monitor disease progression. The following finding was obtained fromher recent test. What does the wave marked by the arrow indicate?MARROW
questions.explanation: The wave marked is the "B" wave. It represents the activity of bipolar cells.Electroretinogram (ERG) is used to detect the functional abnormality of the outer retina up to thebipolar cells.573Electroretinogram (ERG)BNowWIt has 3 waves:A wave - arising from rods and cones (photoreceptors)B wave-generated by Muller cells and representsC wave-the activity of the bipolar cellsrepresents the metabolic activity ofpigment epitheliumOMARROW

questions.question: You would classify the electrooculography (EOG) of a patient as subnormal if the Arden ratiois less than
questions.explanation: In electrooculography (EOG), the subnormal curve is <150.EOG is based on the measurement of the resting membrane potential of the eye betweenthe cornea (+) and the back of the eye (-). Interpretation is based on the Arden ratio.Arden Ratio = Max height of light peak/Min height of dark trough × 100•Normal curve: 185 or above•Subnormal curve: <150• Flat curve: <125GAAT0241LEOGREOG5741

questions.question: You can use 'A' scan for all of the following except:
questions.explanation: Assessment of vitreous hemorrhage is done by "B" scan.Both 'A' and 'B' scans are types of ultrasound (USG) scans.The first image below shows "A" scan ultrasound amplitude spikes.The second image shows a normal "B" scan of the eye.A scan (time amplitude)It produces a unidimensionalimage and echoes are plotted as spikes.Uses:Axial lengthIntraocularlens (IOL) power calculation:BiometryAnterior chamber depthThe thickness of intraocular massB scan (intensity modulation)Itproduces atwo-dimensionaldotted section of the eyeball.Uses: Assessment of the posterior segment in opaque mediaStudy of intraocular tumorsLocalization of intraocular and intra-orbital foreign bodiesA-Scan ultrasound: Amplitude spikesUltrasound probe575Orbital fat

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the instrument in the image?557MARROWOMARROW

options.A: It is used to test macular function
options.B: It is used to measure vertical, horizontal tropias, and phorias
options.C: It cannot be used to measure cyclodeviation
options.D: It is based on diplopic projection

questions.explanation: The image shows a Maddox rod.Cyclodeviation is measured with the double Maddox rod test.The Maddox rod test uses a specially constructed device consisting of a series of parallel cylindersthat converts a point source of light into a line image.It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction withanother Maddox rod, for cyclodeviations.

questions.question: A woman came to the OPD due to blurring of vision while working on her laptop.Retinoscopy was performed at 1 m without cycloplegia. The red reflex moves in the samedirection as the retinoscope. Which of the following refractive errors is not possible in thispatient?
questions.explanation: A patient with 1 D myopia would exhibit no movement of red reflex when retinoscopy is donefrom a distance of 1m without cycloplegia.576MRetinoscopyFindingRed reflex mo VESwith motionHad nofloxRed reflexVs obliquelyGMARROWMyopiaVyopia < 10Astigmatism

questions.question: You can use keratometry for all of the following except:

options.C: Calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL)558
options.D: Calculating the power of lens in spectacles

questions.explanation: Keratometry or ophthalmometry is not used to calculate the power of the lens in spectacles.Uses of keratometry:• Estimate corneal astigmatism• Measure the curvature of the cornea• Calculate the power of the intraocular lens (IOL)The image given below shows keratometry being performed on a patient.577

questions.question: An old man comes to the OPD for an annual eye exam. The ophthalmologist examines hisfundus as shown below. Identify the procedure.
questions.explanation: The procedure shown is direct ophthalmoscopy. It is used to visualize the fundus.Types:• Direct ophthalmoscopy• Distant direct ophthalmoscopy• Indirect ophthalmoscopy

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about direct ophthalmoscopy?

options.C: The type of image formed is real and inverted.
options.D: A condensing lens is not needed.

questions.explanation: The type of image formed in direct ophthalmoscopy is virtual and erect.

questions.question: Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?559AGA

options.A: The principle is to make eye emmetropic.
options.B: Image is real, inverted, and magnified.
options.D: It may be done even in patient's with a hazy media.

questions.explanation: The procedure is indirect ophthalmoscopy and its principle is to make the eye highly myopic.A convex lens is used, commonly +20D. The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified. It isused for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. It maybe done with hazy media because of strong inbuilt illumination.

questions.question: Which of the following can you assess using Holmgren's wool-matching test?
questions.explanation: Holmgren's wool-matching test is used for the assessment of color vision.Tests for color vision•⚫ Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart• There are 38 plates read at a distance of 75 cm.• Drawback- Cannot detect a blue color defect•.Hardy-Rand-Rittler test• City University test• Holmgren's wool-matching test• Naegels anamoloscope• Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue testThe image given below shows Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart578Farnsworth-Munsell 100-hue testCity University test579Hardy-Rand-Ritter test

questions.question: What is the name of the dye in the strip?560
questions.explanation: The given dye in the strip is lissamine green. It is used as 1% concentration.Lissamine green stains dead and degenerate cells, but does not stain healthy epithelial cells. It isused to diagnose ocular surface disease.It stains the conjunctiva. It does not cause stinging like Rose Bengal. The Green staining is bestobserved two minutes after instillation.The image below shows the lissamine staining of the eye.EyeRounds.org580

questions.question: The device shown below cannot be used in the management of which of the following?
questions.explanation: The image shows a cryoprobe. It is not used in the management of impending corneal perforation.It is used in:••Peripheral retinopexy for peripherally located retinal breaks and tears• Treatment of anterior RB tumors⚫ Cyclocryotherapy in pars planitis and end-stage glaucoma

questions.question: The following image indicates:
questions.explanation: The given image is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy.The central image shows the primary position of gaze where the patient's left eye is deviated downand out with ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements in other positions, it can be seenthat adduction and elevation are absent and depression is reduced in the left eye. All of thesefindings are indicative of oculomotor nerve palsy.3rd Cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy presents with:• Ptosis due to weakness of levator palpebrae superioris muscle (LPS)•Abduction and depression in the primary position (down and out) due to unopposed action ofthe lateral rectus(6th nerve supply) and superior oblique muscles(4th nerve supply)•Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy (involvement ofEdinger Westphal parasympathetic supply)• Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to ipsilateral paralysis of medial rectus, inferioroblique and inferior rectus.Signs of Oculomotor Nerve PalsyDescriptionProfound plosis due toVAZONES İness of levatorAbduction1° gaze duG to unopposednotion of lateral rootus& Superior obliqueIntorsion due to intactsuperior obliqueLimitaci depressiondue to VVEAk interiorroctusLimited elevation due toInferior obliquoDilatedpupil duestoAsjud oneujiochiUASGudNormal abduotion(C) MARROVAVEOption A: Trochlear(4th cranial) nerve palsy presents with superior oblique muscle paralysis.Clinical findings of trochlear nerve palsy include:581•Hypertropia (elevation) in the primary position• Extorsion that is greatest in abduction•Compensatory head posture with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightlydepressed. This position is assumed to avoid Diplopia.• Limitation of depression• Normal abduction and elevation.The below given image depicts 4th cranial nerve palsy.M0OMARROWOption B: Lateral rectus palsy is seen in cases of isolated Abducens nerve palsy. These patientspresent with esotropia/convergent squint in primary position with limitation of abduction on theside of the lesion. This is due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle in the affected eye.There is also a compensatory head turn towards the side of the lesion to reduce the symptom ofDiplopia. The adduction is normal in lateral rectus palsy.Affected ayeadductsappropriatelyLook rightCN VI palsyLook straight aheadRightLeftAffected eye is adducted (medial strabismus)Superior rentus (CN IIDLateral rectus(GN VDInferior oblique (CN IDInferior rectus (CN TID.@MARROW582Look loftAffectedabductdiplopiaSuperior obliqu(CN IVInferior obliqueecial rectuam(GN IDSuperior obliqueOption C: Internuclear opthalmoplegia occurs following an injury to the medial longitudinalfasciculus (MLF). A unilateral lesion to the MLF leads to the failure of adduction in the ipsilateraleye with a normal abduction of the contralateral eye.The below given image depicts the pathogenesis of Inter nuclear opthalmoplegia in detail.REI/L adductionabsentPrimary gazeRight gaze(Normal)Left gaze(defect)OMARROWLEC/L abduction presentwith nystagmusAnatomical pathway for horizontaleye movementsRight FEFMARight EyeMR3rdMLFPPRE6thLeft EyePPRFFEFMLFMRParamedian pontine reticular formationFrontal eye fieldMedial longitudinal fasciculusMedial rectusLRLateral rectusOMARROWLR

questions.question: Photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.explanation: Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve.This test is of particular use in early macular diseases such as central serous retinopathy.In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart.A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the lineagain, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.583In normal people and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected.Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more thanone-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors aredamaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.584
